resources.string: Do you want to exit podo?
Do you have something to tell \'podo\'? \n (bug report or suggestions)
Things you can do with points
Writing: Ask a Korean teacher for correction
Attend for 7 days in a row (see profile page)
You can get 3 points for every mission you complete.
If you complete all missions, you will get an additional 5 points.
"Do you want to go back to main?\n(You can be rewarded points when you finish the lesson)"
"Do you want to go back to main?"
How to say numbers in Korean

"Many Korean learners think Korean numbers are really difficult. Because there are two systems of Korean numbers(Sino-Korean number / Native-Korean number) and you should use each number system depending on what the number is used for. Therefore whenever students say numbers, they are confused about which system of number to use.
In general, each number system is used in the following situations:
1. Sino-Korean number: Number itself 2. Native-Korean number: Counting numbers (that's why we should use this with an 'unit noun' together)
But when you learn Korean numbers, you can see that this rule is not always correct. (For example, why the hour is Native-Korean number but the minute is Sino-Korean number?)
So I suggest to students 'Just listen and follow the correct number a lot. Then you will feel something strange right before you try to use the wrong number.'
This lesson is designed to learn Sino-Korean number and Native-Korean number as well as to practice the numbers repeatedly in different situations.
Let's practice until '일시 오분' and '십살' seem strange!"
You can do better next time!
You need at least \'18/20\' to go to the next stage

"Learn minimum words and expressions that you mostly use everyday."
"Don't waste your time and effort to learn something you don't use often."
"Focuses on practicing what you've learned so far."
"Stop learning new words and expressions for a while."
"Make sentences using only what you've learned in the beginner lessons."
"It's time to upgrade your expressiveness by learning new(more advanced) words and expressions."
Writing should be at least 20 letters.
Are you sure want to delete this writing?
Request is submitted. You\'ll get the feedback in 2days.

You can practice writing and request a correction from a native Korean teacher by using 1 point per 1 letter. Feedback will be provided in 100% Korean. (Inappropriate writing such as abusive language may be rejected)
What is the most effective way to learn Korean?
Among a lot of students I taught, I asked the students who improved their Korean skills the fastest how to learn.
Take time to practice almost everyday. It does not necessarily have to be through reading or studying in a book. Some days I might only watch videos on youtube or listen to a podcast.

At the beginning, try to get a basic understanding of the grammar but do not focus exclusively on it. In order to increase my vocabulary, focus on the most commonly used words first, do not worry about memorizing every single word. Take time to practice almost everyday. It does not necessarily have to be through reading or studying in a book. Some days I might only watch videos on youtube or listen to a podcast. If you can, try to get in touch with someone else who shares your interest in learning Korean. I mostly study alone, but once a week I meet other students who are learning Korean where I live. In that way, I think that I can increase my motivation to study and make it more fun.
Korean is a beautiful language but definitely not the easiest. That is why I try to surround myself with it as mush as possible.

When it comes to learning a new language, the most important thing is to find something of genuine interest for me. Korean is a beautiful language but definitely not the easiest. That is why I try to surround myself with it as mush as possible, by listening to music and podcasts, watching YouTube videos on various topics, with and without subtitles. Naver\'s daily Korean conversation is also a good way to improve your listening skills and vocabulary with casual useful conversations.
Learn grammar & vocabulary steadily and review everything once a month. And watch & listen as much everyday Korean contents. (movies, dramas, musics or even TV show).

Personally, I try to work my Korean by following these few steps :
 - Learn grammar & vocabulary steadily and review everything once a month.
 - Use what I learn by writing examples and ask teacher to check and correct.
 - Watch & listen as much everyday Korean contents. (movies, dramas, musics or even TV show).
Be exposed to Korean as much as possible every day.

"As a Korean teacher, I totally agree.
The Korean language you are learning is not a field of study.
It’s everyday life.

Consistently learning in everyday life is the fastest and most powerful way to speak Korean."
TO YOU WHO WANT TO LEARN KOREAN QUICKLY
Complete all beginner/intermediate lessons of podo in 30 days!
Learning the minimum words and expressions used most in everyday life, about 260 words, 45 expressions (1st~25th days)
Practice everyday conversation using only words and expressions learned in the beginner lesson (26th~30th days)
All lessons were made and recorded by myself, a Korean teacher.
Daily goal progress indicator\n(Try achieving your goal\nevery day for 30 days.)

1,000 points will be provided
upon reaching the final goal
within the challenge period
($20 value)
What can you do with the points?

After completing all the beginner and intermediate lessons, it\'s time to learn new vocabulary and expressions.\n\nYou can use your points to continue your desired learning among the various methods below.
After 30 days you can speak Korean.

This is an easy-to-read article written by a Korean teacher using only the easiest words and expressions as possible. You can also practice correct pronunciation through audio recorded by the teacher.
Write what you want to say in Korean. The Korean teacher directly provides correction and supplementary explanations.

"Korean verbs and adjectives have a base form. Base form ends with '~다' such as '먹다 (to eat)', '가다 (to go)' and '사다 (to buy)'.
You'll need to look up the word as a base form on a dictionary, but when you actually use a word in a conversation or writing you should transform it into the form that you want to express. For example, '먹다 (to eat)' changes as below.
- 먹다 (to eat) : base form - 먹어요 (I eat) - 먹으면 (if I eat) - 먹어서 (because I eat) - 먹고나서 (after I eat)
Mostly you can only change the last syllable '~다' of the base form into the other form, but sometimes there are irregular words that you have to change not only '~다' but also the other syllables as well. For example...
- 듣다 (to listen / base form) - 들어요 (I listen) - 들으면 (If I listen) - 들어서(because I listen) - 듣고나서(after I listen)
Many students think that irregular words are difficult, but you don't need to worry because most of the irregular forms are for easier pronunciation. In the example above, you can pronounce the word easier by changing it irregularly into '들어요[드러요]' instead of '듣어요[드더요]'. Therefore, if you use it several times through speaking practice, you will be able to remember irregular words naturally."

"The first conjugation you will learn is the '아요/어요' form(Shortly call '아/어요' form). '아/어요' form is not too formal but can sound polite enough. Therefore, it is used often in everyday conversation.
There are three rules to transform the base form into '아/어요'. Let's take a look at the example. (You don't need to know the meaning of the words in the example right now. Let's focus on the process of changing the base form into '아/어요' form.)
1.
하다 -> 해요 : The base form of a verb or adjective ending with '~하다' can be simply changed to '해요'.
ex) 공부하다 -> 공부해요 운동하다 -> 운동해요 좋아하다 -> 좋아해요
2.
If the syllable before '~다' has 'ㅏ' or 'ㅗ' vowel -> '아요' : You should check the syllable right before the '~다' In the base form. If the syllable has 'ㅏ' or 'ㅗ' vowel, this word should be added with '아요'. Let's take a look at the word '가다'. The previous syllable of '다' is '가' and '가' has a vowel 'ㅏ'. Therefore, the word '가다' is conjugated to '가' + '아요' = '가아요', and '가아요' can be simplified to '가요'.
ex) '오다' -> '오' + '아요' = '오아요' -> '와요' '만나다' -> '만나' + '아요' = '만나아요' -> '만나요' '살다' -> '살' + '아요' -> '살아요'
3.
Every word except 1 and 2 -> '어요' : Let's look at the word '먹다. This word doesn't end with '하다'. And since the vowels of the '먹' is 'ㅓ', it's not fall into the type 2 as well. Therefore, this word is type 3 and you can add '어요' after the base form.
ex) '먹다' -> '먹' + '어요' = '먹어요' '배우다' -> '배우' + '어요' = '배우어요' -> '배워요' '읽다' -> '읽' + '어요' = '읽어요'
So far, we have looked at the '아/어요' and let's make a promise with me now. Just think about this rule until Lesson 10 and forget about this. Actually there are only a few Koreans who know this rule. When you learn new verbs or adjectives, just take a look '아/어요' as well. And just say '아요' or '어요' as it is pronounced comfortably. It might be correct.
I'm going to give you one more interesting thing and finish this lesson. The '아/어요' is very powerful that it can have a various meanings depending on the way you speak or the situation.
For example, let's see the word '먹어요'. a. "먹어요." (You eat) b. "먹어요?" (Do you eat?) c. "먹어요!!" (You must eat!) There are more meanings, but let's just remember type 'a' and 'b' from above examples."

"Particles in Korean is quite hard for those students who use language which doesn't have particles. The most difficult particles are '은/는', '이/가' and '을/를'. We'll learn each particle later and I'm going to explain why korean use particles in this lesson.
There are two sentences in English as below. 1. I eat lion. 2. Lion eat I. (Of course, 'The lion eats me' is the correct sentence but ignore it for now)
The subject of sentence 1 is 'I' and the object is 'lion'. However, the subject of sentence 2 is 'lion' and the object is 'I'. In english, depending on the position of the word in the sentence structure, the subject and the object can be determined and the meanings of sentences become completely different.
Now let's look at the Korean sentence using particles. 1. 나는 사자를 먹어요 2. 사자를 나는 먹어요 In the first sentence, subject particle '는' is added after '나' meaning 'I', and object particle '를' is added after '사자' meaning 'lion' in the second sentence. When you use particles the role of the word is fixed, so the sentence always has the same meaning no matter where you put the word. Therefore, sentence 1 and 2 is totally same meaning as 'I eat lion'.
This is the difference between language that use particles and language does not use particles. But it's not a good idea to change the position of words all the time. In general Korean language structure is 'subject-object-predicate', so it would be better to follow this order."

"There are 2 basic tips to improve your pronunciation.
1. The consonant 'ㅇ' is a silent consonant(Only if it's not a Batchim). Therefore, when there is a syllable which has a Batchim before the consonant 'ㅇ' syllable, the Batchim can replace the next syllable's consonant 'ㅇ' to read it naturally. For example, '사람이에요' has a Batchim 'ㅁ' in the syllable '람' and the next syllable '이' has a consonant 'ㅇ' which is a silent phoneme. So you can pronounce it like [사라미에요].
2. Batchim 'ㅎ' makes the sound of following syllable stronger. If the syllables which composed with 'ㄱ', 'ㄷ', 'ㅈ' comes after or before the syllable with 'ㅎ', they sound like 'ㅋ', 'ㅌ', 'ㅊ' respectively. ex) - 좋다 -> [조타] - 놓고 -> [노코] - 많지 -> [만치]"

"1. 5시에 운동을 해요. 2. 5시에서 운동을 해요.
Which one is correct?
1.
You can use '~에' after the 'time/hour', so this sentence is correct.
ex) - 5시에 운동을 해요. - 아침에 학교를 가요. - 저녁에 약속이 있어요.
2.
You should use '~에서' after the 'place/location' not 'time' so this sentence is incorrect.
ex) - 학교에서 한국어를 공부해요. - 집에서 TV를 봐요. - 식당에서 밥을 먹어요.
It may sound easy so far. Let's learn a little further now.
2-1.
There's some case that you have to use '~에' following after a 'place/location'. When you want to talk about the existence('있다/없다') or movement('가다/오다/도착하다/다니다...'), you can use '~에' after the noun indicating the place.
ex) - 서점에 책이 있어요. - 밖에 사람이 없어요. - 병원에 가요. - 어제 한국에 도착했어요. - 한국어 학교에 다녀요.
In a nutshell, you can use '~에' unconditionally after the noun indicating the time, and basically you can use '~에서' after the noun indicating the place. But sometimes you can use '~에' after the noun indicating the place depending on the verb of the sentence."

"How do you say below words in Korean?
- Bibimbap restaurant - Spaghetti restaurant - tteokbokki restaurant
- 비빔밥 식당 - 스파게티 식당 - 떡볶이 식당
Does it sound right?
Restaurant is '식당' in Korean but native Korean often say 'food' + '집'(house) instead of saying 'food' + 식당(restaurant). So above example sentences can be changed as below.
- 비빔밥집 - 스파게티집 - 떡볶이집
This way sounds more natural. Then, how can you say Korean restaurant in Korean? Korean food is called '한국 음식' or shortly '한식' so you can say '한식집' or '한식당'."

"1.
As you learned in the previous lesson, '아서/어서' is a reason or cause.
ex) - 만나서 반가워요. ('만나다' -> '만나서') - 저거는 50% 세일이어서 5,000원이에요. ('이다' -> '이어서') - 겨울이어서 날씨가 추워요. ('이다' -> '이어서')
In '이다 -> 이어서' case, it is better to say '이라서' in the actual conversation as below - 저거는 50% 세일이라서 5,000원이에요. - 겨울이라서 날씨가 추워요.
2.
You can also use '아서/어서' to describe the timeline of two happenings. In this case, there must be a close connection between what happened before and what happened afterwards.
ex) - 한국에 가서 한국어를 배워요. - 친구를 만나서 얘기해요. - 식당에 가서 밥을 먹어요."

"Neologism' is often created by young generation and become popular. Some people say that it's better not to use it because it's not a standard language. But I think foreigners can learn Korean more fun through the newly-coined word or abbreviation. However, some words are not recommended to use in a formal situation.
Below words are the most common used newly-coined words recently.
1. 인플루언서 : This is a loanword adopted from English word 'influencer'. '인플루언서' is an individual who has a large number of followers in social media and power to affect opinion and decisions of other people.
2. 편스토랑 : A combination of '편의점 (convenience store)' and '레스토랑 (restaurant)'. It's a convenience store where you can have a quality meal like a restaurant.
3. 소떡소떡 : It's a Korean street food snack that skewered alternately '소시지 (sausage)' with '떡 (rice cake)' and baked. That's why it is called '소떡소떡'.
4. 스포 : It's from English word 'spoiler'. It's an behavior or piece of plot that reveals critical part like ending of of the movie/drama/show.
5. 꾸안꾸 : This is an abbreviation of '꾸민 듯 안 꾸민 듯. It means someone's outfit looks natural but not too shady and someone's make-up looks natural that you cannot tell if she/he put on a make-up or not. You can use the word like '꾸안꾸 style'(natural outfit) and '꾸안꾸 make-up'(natural make-up)."

"You might wonder why there are Chinese character lesson. Since Korea used Chinese characters in the past, there are lots of words made from Chinese characters.
Usually in a formal writing, the high level of vocabulary derived from Chinese character is used. Therefore, if you don't know the words from Chinese character, you could be overwhelmed by many unfamiliar words when you start reading Korean articles.
However, because each Chinese character has its own meaning, learning a few easy Chinese characters can help you to understand the meaning of Korean words better. Therefore, let's study a few easy Chinese characters.
The first Chinese character we will learn is '人'(사람 인). This Chinese character has the meaning of '사람'(people) and you can read it as '인'. The shape of this letter is also very interesting. This letter represents a human's walking posture. Therefore, if there is a syllable '인' in Korean word, we can guess that it is related to 'people'.
ex) - 한국인 : Korean - 인간 : human - 인구 : population - 인격 : personality"

"1. 저는 스키를 좋아요. 2. 저는 스키를 좋아해요.
Which one is correct?
1. The base form of '좋아요' is '좋다'(adjective) and it can be used after the subject(which is able to use with '이/가'). But first sentence put '좋아요' after object which is incorrect, so you have to change it like '저는 스키가 좋아요'.
ex) - 저는 치킨이 좋아요. - 오늘은 날씨가 좋아요.
2.
The base form of '좋아해요' is '좋아하다'(verb) and it can be used after the object(which is able to use with '을/를'). So this sentence sounds natural.
ex) - 저는 치킨을 좋아해요. - 눈이 오는 날씨를 좋아해요."

" 1.
1) 시간이 없어서 빨리 가세요. 2) 시간이 없으니까 빨리 가세요.
Which one is correct?
'아/어서' is not allowed in 'order' or 'request' statements. Therefore, sentence 1) is a weird sentence. Likewise, instead of '이 식당은 비빔밥이 맛있어서 비빔밥 먹으세요', '이 식당은 비빔밥이 맛있으니까 비빔밥 먹으세요' is the correct expression.
2.
1) 한국에 살았어서 한국어를 잘해요. 2) 한국에 살았으니까 한국어를 잘해요.
Which one is correct?
'으니까' is not available for past tense. Therefore, sentence 1) is correct.
3.
1) 만나서 반가워요. 2) 만났으니까 반가워요.
Which one is correct?
Everyone can easily see that 1) is the right sentence. But you may not know why. '으니까' cannot be used in adjectives expressing emotions. For example, '반갑다', '고맙다', '미안하다'.
SUMMARY) There are three rules, but you don't have to remember them all. Usually, you can use '아/어서' and use '으니까' only when expressing 'order' or 'request'. "

"여기 : here 저기 : there 거기 : there
It's easy to know '여기' and '저기', but there are also a word '거기' in Korean. In English, '저기' and '거기' are translated as 'there'. What is the difference?
1.
It can be identified as the place of the speaker and listener.
'여기': a place close to the speaker
ex) - 여기로 오세요. : Come here. - 여기 앉으세요. : Sit down here.
'저기': a place far away from both the speaker and the listener. In other words, the speaker and the listener are currently in the same place and talking about 'there(저기)' where is far from both speaker and listner.
ex) - 저기에 뭐가 있어요? : What is there? - 저기로 가요 : Let's go there.
'거기': A place close to the listener. In other words, the speaker and the listener are not in the same place and are talking about the 'there(거기)' where the listener is.
ex) - 거기는 날씨가 어때요? : What's the weather there? - 거기에 어떻게 가요? : How can I get there?
2.
In addition, there is one more thing to know about '거기'. We use '거기' when we talk about a place that was once mentioned during a conversation.
ex) - 저기에 가 보세요. 거기에 물이 있어요. : Go over there. There's some water. - 저기에서 기다리세요. 데니 씨가 거기로 갈 거예요. : Wait over there. Denny will be there. "

"1.
- Indirect expression
You can speak your thoughts directly and strongly, but you can also express them indirectly. In this case, the '~(으)ㄴ/는 것 같다' form, which means guess, can also be used to indirectly say my thoughts.
ex)
한국 음식 맛있는 것 같아요. (I think Korean food is yummy.) 한국 드라마 재미있는 것 같아요. (I think Korean drama is interesting.) 한국어 공부 쉬운 것 같아요. (I think learning Korean is easy.)
English speaking students usually say their thoughts, '저는 생각해요. blabla...'. Because in English, they say 'I think blabla...'. Of course we can understand that, but if you use the form '~(으)ㄴ/는 것 같다', you will be able to speak your thoughts in a more natural Korean language.
2.
- About negative answer
We'd learned to use '안' or '못' to make negative statements. And we learned '~지 않아요' or '~지 못해요' in the same meaning.
However, depending on the situation, these negative statements could be too direct expression.
For example, if someone asks me and I say '못 해요' in the situation that I can't accept the request, it's too direct to be an excuse to the other person. In this case, if you use '~(으)ㄹ 것 같아요', you can speak negative sentences more polite.
In other words, '못 해요' -> '못 할 것 같아요' '안 해요' -> '안 할 것 같아요' could be a better expression.
ex) "이따가 헬스장에 같이 가요." "오늘 바빠서 못 갈 것 같아요."
"내일 아침 같이 먹어요." "안 될 것 같아요." "피곤해서 일찍 못 일어날 것 같아요.""

"1.
The difference between '뭐' and '무슨' is not difficult. '뭐' + Verb '무슨' + Noun
Let's Take a look at the conversation below.
ex)
어제 뭐 했어요? // 뭐 + 하다(Verb) 공부했어요. 무슨 공부 했어요? // 무슨 + 공부(Noun) 한국어 공부 했어요.
2.
Now let's compare '무슨' and '어떤'.
'무슨 공부 했어요?' '어떤 공부 했어요?'
In real life, the above two sentences are almost same.
However,
In more detail, '무슨' is asking about what the object itself is. '어떤' is asking about it's characteristics, content, and personality etc.
Therefore, depending on the situation, it may be necessary to distinguish between '무슨' and '어떤'.
For example,
'데니 씨는 무슨 사람이에요?' '데니 씨는 어떤 사람이에요?'
Asking '무슨 사람' can be used in situations that you don't know who '데니 씨' is. However, it is more natural to use '누구'(who) rather than '무슨 사람'. Therefore, '데니 씨는 누구예요?' is correct.
In situations that you know already who '데니 씨' is and ask about his personality or characteristics, you should use '어떤'.
Let's take one more example.
'어제 본 영화 무슨 영화예요?' '어제 본 영화 어떤 영화예요?'
If you look at the answer to the above sentence, it will be easy to understand.
'어제 본 영화 무슨 영화예요?' -> 'Lion king 이에요.' '어제 본 영화 어떤 영화예요?' -> '재미있는 영화예요.'"

"'가게 밖으로 나가서 오른쪽으로 가세요.'
In the last lesson, we learned '(으)로' as a direction. However, in addition to the direction, there are a lot of other meanings. Let's learn only 3 more meanings with some examples that are often used in daily life.
1. way, method a. 버스로 왔어요. (I came by bus.) b. 비행기로 1시간 걸려요. (It takes a hour by plane.) c. 한국어로 말해요. (Speak in Korean.) d. 숟가락으로 아이스크림을 먹어요. (I eat ice cream with a spoon.)
2. material, ingredient a. 안 입는 옷으로 가방을 만들었어요. (I made a bag with clothes that I don't wear.) b. 오렌지로 주스를 만들었어요. (I made juice from orange.) c. 떡볶이는 쌀로 만들어요. (Tteokbokki is made from rice.)
3. reason, cause a. 코로나 바이러스로 많은 사람들이 힘들었어요. (The corona virus made it difficult for many people.) b. 맛있는 음식으로 스트레스가 풀렸어요. (The stress had been relieved by the delicious food.) c. 한국 드라마로 한국에 흥미가 생겼어요. (I got interested in Korea by a Korean drama.) "

"- 이따 전화 할게요. - 이따 전화 할 거예요.
What's difference of 2 sentences above? When translated into English, they are both 'will' or 'be going to'. Therefore, students often misuse them.
The difference between the two is very simple. - '~(으)ㄹ게요' : Promise between the speaker and the listener - '~(으)ㄹ 거예요' : Only the speaker's plan, will / future tense
In other words, when using'~(으)ㄹ게요', it is natural in the situation where a consensus is formed between the speaker and the listener. - ""조용히 좀 해주세요."" (Please be quiet.) ""미안해요. 밖에 나갈게요."" (I'm sorry. I'll go out.) - ""지금 좀 바빠요."" (I'm a little busy now.) ""그럼 나중에 다시 전화 할게요."" (Then, I'll call you again later.) - ""맛있게 드세요."" (Please enjoy this food.) ""고마워요. 잘 먹을게요."" (Thank you. I'll eat well.)
And when you want to express your will, such as a simple future or a new year goal, it is good to use '~(으)ㄹ 거예요' as follows.. - 내일 비가 올 거예요. (It will rain tomorrow.) - 새해에는 한국어를 열심히 공부할 거예요! (I'll study Korean hard in the new year!) - 한국 여행을 가면 떡볶이를 먹을 거예요. (When I go on a trip to Korea, I'll eat Tteokbokki.)"

"- 커피를 마시러 카페에 가요. - 커피를 마시려고 카페에 가요.
Are these two sentences correct or wrong?
Both are correct sentences.
Then, Let's look at the next sentences.
1. 커피를 마시러 카페를 샀어요. 2. 커피를 마시려고 카페를 샀어요.
Only the verb changed '가다' to '샀다', but are both sentences correct again?
No.
1 is wrong and only 2 is correct now. Why?
1. In the previous lesson, the reason for saying '(으)러 가다' form instead of '(으)러' is the only verbs that have the meaning of 'movement', such as '가다', '오다', '올라가다' and '나오다', can be followed after '(으)러'.
In other words, the '(으)러' form is an expression to explain 'The reason of movement'.
2. Let's look at the next sentences to see the second difference.
1. 커피를 마시러 카페에 갈 거예요. 2. 커피를 마시려고 카페에 갈 거예요.
Both sentences are used the future tense. Now, which sentence is correct now?
The answer is no.1.
'(으)러' can be used in all past, present and future tense. However, '(으)려고' can only be used in the past and present tense. It cannot be used in the future tense.
In other words, '(으)려고' is an expression to explain 'The reason of the situation that has already occurred or is in progress'. "

"As we learned before, the two expressions are very similar.
- 뭐 좀 먹을까요? = 뭐 좀 먹을래요? - 이제 나갈까요? = 이제 나갈래요?
1. Common Both expressions have the meaning of 'Shall we ~ together'. So, you can use it with '같이' as below.
- 뭐 좀 (같이) 먹을까요? = 뭐 좀 (같이) 먹을래요? - 이제 (같이) 나갈까요? = 이제 (같이) 나갈래요?
2. Difference: '~(으)ㄹ까요?' '~(으)ㄹ까요?' is used to suggest my opinion to the other person. Let's take a look at the example again.
- 뭐 좀 먹을까요? - 이제 나갈까요?
Likewise, depending on the situation, it could be 'I' not 'together'.
For example, - 저는 너무 배고파요. (저) 먼저 뭐 좀 먹을까요? : I'm so hungry. Can I eat something first? - 피곤해요? (저) 이제 나갈까요? : Are you tired? Shall I go out now?
3. Difference: '~(으)ㄹ래요?' '~(으)ㄹ래요?' is used to ask for the other person's opinion. Let's take a look at the example,
- 뭐 좀 먹을래요? - 이제 나갈래요?
Depending on the situation, it could be 'only you' not 'together'.
For example, - 배고파요? (너) 뭐 좀 먹을래요? : Are you hungry? Do you want to eat some food? - 저 피곤해요. (너) 이제 나갈래요? : I'm tired. Can you go out now?
4. One more : '~(으)ㄹ래요.' This time, I didn't write a question mark after '~(으)ㄹ래요'. Because it is used when talking about my 'will' rather than asking for the other person's opinion.
So you can use it like this: - 뭐 좀 먹을래요. : I'll eat something. - 이제 나갈래요. : I'll go out now. "

"The words spoken to a person of the same age or younger is called '반말', and the words spoken to people who are older than me or who have a higher social position are called '존댓말'(honorific).
Many Korean learners find it difficult to say this '존댓말'. And they also like the most of the Korean culture that respects others with '존댓말'.
In general, the way to make honorifics in Korean is to use the '(으)시' form that we learned in the previous lesson. However, there are a lot of words that don't use the '(으)시' form and have completely new words. Let's take a look at some of the most used words in everyday life.
1. 주다(give) -> 드리다 - 선물을 드리다. - 인사를 드리다.
2. 먹다(eat) -> 드시다 - 물을 드시다. - 빵을 드시다.
3. 있다(be) -> 계시다 - 집에 계시다. - 회사에 계시다.
4. 아프다(sick) -> 편찮으시다 - 몸이 편찮으시다.
5. 죽다(die) -> 돌아가시다 - 할아버지께서 돌아가시다.
6. 생일(birthday) -> 생신 - 생신 축하드려요.
"
